comments.commentBody: This one may make me swear off Sundays completely.  Most of us solve the puzzle before getting on the blog, so all these instructions after the fact don't really help much.  Is there a way I can subscribe to just the Thursday through Saturday puzzles?

I certainly hope he voted against Qatar as that makes a lot more sense out of this comment. If he voted for Qatar this is something he and FIFA should have been considering as a condition of having the WC there, not an afterthought. But if he opposed Qatar's bid this makes a lot of sense: now that the vote is over he is trying to offer ways to deal with his concerns with the bid. There's nothing wrong with that and I'm relieved that at least someone at FIFA is thinking about reality.

As for whether or not it is going to happen I highly doubt it given league schedules but 11 years out I suppose anything is possible. We don't even have a good idea what the security situation will be in the Middle East (or anywhere really) then. This is one of the problems of picking so early.

So, the situation in Qatar ISN'T settled up front as it is supposed to be BEFORE the vote takes place.  Where in their bid was the possibility of a January Cup?  This idea, coming now, from an Executive Committee member and possible future President, truly exposes the bidding as corrupt, and rigged.

No one has pointed out that FIFA will give an automatic invite to the Qatari (sp?) team as part of the winning bid. Having heard howls back in '94 when we (US) made it largely on the basis of hosting, and last year when everyone thought SA would be laughed out of it's own stadiums (despite having EPL players), what are we going to see on the field representing Qatar? Have they ever made it close to qualifying? Do they have a team? Will FIFA let them buy/field a team of foreign players?

NYT editor: Qatar's FIFA ranking through the years (http://www.fifa.com/associations/association=qat/ranking/gender=m/index.html). It's currently a three-digit number. AD

So big of Jeter to take a hometown "discount" despite nearly a dozen "mystery" teams vying for his talents. Oh wait..it was Hal & Hank bidding against themselves again. Apparently they also drank the Jeter cool aid and believed that no fans would go to the Stadium had they not sign him.

I printed the puzzle from AcrossLite, and so missed much of the experience. I could just as easily have printed from a PDF, had I but known.  It was a little frustrating to try to fill out clues when something visual was obviously missing, and I don't read the blog until after I've finished the puzzle, but... c'est la vie.  Or la guerre.  Anyway, I did finish it, although I thought your die was a Christmas tree ornament at first (it may still become one).

The fewer the government secrets, the stronger we are as a society.

half the story is the actual documents.the other half is all about state secrecy.and its growth.
so much is justified by national interest.
the implication; at any any cost.
we need to reconsider this.
that was the basis for the united nations.
that my national interest does not over ride anyone elses.
and the citizens have a right to know and question everything of their
politicians.

"Knowledge will forever govern ignorance; and a people who mean to be their own governors must arm themselves with the power which knowledge gives." - James Madison

After the neverending chain of lies from Vietnam to WMDs, from the toxic waste of banks (Wikileaks now promises to begin leaking financial secrets), why on earth should a populace continue to remain ignorant? If wikileaks had leaked the Downing Street memo or many internal CIA documents establishing the doubts of WMDs in Iraq, would we have gone? that in and of itself is a raison d'etre for this service.

Only those who have something to hide are afraid of the light.
Gentlemen don't read other gentlemens' mail.

So then, could journalists and pundits at the Times stop bashing Assange and feeding off of his revelations? Either you report on the leaks with enthusiasm and embrace Assange, or you despise him and try to put a lid on the leaks (or at least not participate in it). You can't have it both ways. This whole we-are-concerned-too-but-we-decide-to-publish-anyway-but-Assange-is-definitely-a-bad-guy charade is sickening.
So Wikileaks was irresponsible and dangerous, but NY Times was principled and brave. Hmm.

Regrettably, people will die because of these leaks. Yet, the leaks give me much more confidence in the government of the United States of America.

Nevertheless, I want to have the information myself; I do not want the newspapers to hold it in trust for me.

I remember the lying liars, Johnson, Rusk, and McNamara, who never stopped moaning about the great moral burden they carried. Rusk went to his grave with his moral superiority and higher knowledge defense intact.

Some leaked cables would have helped in 1964. We needed them.

There's no question that this material must be published. How else are we to have the ghost of a chance of learning a scintilla of what's really going on in the world. From the "official" pronouncements of our public officials?

William McCloskey, Pittsburgh

Unfortunately, Mr. Brisbane is glossing over a major problem with the Times' BM-25 missile story. Contrary to what he asserts, the original times article was no "first step" towards the truth. It was, rather, an exercise in lying by omission. By failing to publish the original cable, or accurately describe its contents (in particular the Russian dismissal of the US claims) the times bought wholesale into the US diplomats' story, burying contrary information that was available to the Times at the time of publication.

Moreover, this problem of buying into whatever US diplomat wrote in the cables as if it were fact - even in instances where the cables were based on second- and third-hand information from unidentified sources - has persisted throughout the Times' coverage. To give but one additional example, the Times headline of their discussion of cables claiming China engaged in hacking attacks against google reads:

"Cables Discuss Vast Hacking by a China That Fears the Web",
thereby implicitly assuming the factual truth of the allegations made by US diplomats. The Guardian, on the other hand, titles more accurately:

"Cables blame Chinese for hacking Google"

This practice of the Times of taking anything US officials say or write at face value, as proven fact, is incredibly dangerous. One might think the Times would have learned that lesson in the run-up to the war in Iraq. Guess not.

The NYT wouldn't have been suppressing the story, nor would The Guardian or any other of the papers who have been working with Assange. The information was all over the Internet and accessible to anyone with a computer, at least until Amazon, Paypal, etc caved into government bullies (although the cables are now available again at a new home). I think you overestimate the Time's role here--and your concluding what-ifs aren't really analogous.

The Acra Hotel is an elegantly
decorated boutique hotelwell located in the heart of the historical
part of the city, just walking distance from
the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and the
Hagia Sophia.Everything was great: the
location, the price, the room size, the
cleanliness, the personnel.I asked for a fruit
basket with a note from me to my wife (as
we were celebrating a special occasion), and
they provided it free of charge. You won’t find
anything better in this price.They arranged free a pickup and dropoff to the
airport.The front desk mr Hasan, , is an absolute
gem. If you like late night clubbing, ask
about Hassan’s club—very cool indeed!He arranged a wonderful halfday boat
trip on the Bosphorus 25 €.He did it all and
always with a smile The customer
service is beyond words I wish all
hotels in the world would be like this!”
We will definitely return to spend more time in Istanbul and we’ll definitely stay at The ACRA Hotel. Highly recommended.

Think of the internet as a sponge...
There are no secrets here...

Governments have used Audio Babble and Written Babble to subject peoples throughout the centuries... Now there is a medium we people can use to unravel Governments and their corrupt practices...
Let's get to it people, it's time...

What China really fears is the innate desire by people to be free. The Chinese government has every reason to fear the internet, and in fact, any medium that can be used to empower people with information. In all the rosy assessments of China's rise to power, why do we fail to factor into the equation the fundamental flaw displayed by Beijing when they fear so much their citizens ability to know the truth. Is this a sign of a "rising" superpower?
